pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 356, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Pure Mathematics 3 (P3)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 590, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 606, 525]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 272, 92]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 94, 578, 112]]<|/det|>
\[\ln (x + 5) = 1 + \ln x,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 384, 136]]<|/det|>
giving your answer in terms of e.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 163, 94, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 163, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
(i) Express \(24 \sin \theta - 7 \cos \theta\) in the form \(R \sin (\theta - \alpha)\), where \(R > 0\) and \(0^\circ < \alpha < 90^\circ\). Give the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 210, 153, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 210, 685, 228]]<|/det|>
Hence find the smallest positive value of \(\theta\) satisfying the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 235, 591, 254]]<|/det|>
\[24\sin \theta -7\cos \theta = 17.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 235, 918, 254]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 290, 96, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 290, 438, 308]]<|/det|>
The parametric equations of a curve are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[378, 316, 618, 345]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{4t}{2t + 3}, \quad y = 2\ln (2t + 3).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 368, 154, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 368, 562, 395]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) in terms of \(t\), simplifying your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 371, 918, 390]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 408, 153, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 408, 623, 427]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at the point for which \(x = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 408, 920, 427]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 454, 96, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 454, 601, 473]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) are related by the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 481, 571, 510]]<|/det|>
\[(x^{2} + 4)\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = 6xy.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 516, 698, 536]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = 32\) when \(x = 0\). Find an expression for \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 516, 920, 536]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 562, 96, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 562, 500, 581]]<|/det|>
The expression \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) is defined by \(\operatorname {f}(x) = 3x\mathrm{e}^{- 2x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 594, 153, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 594, 401, 613]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\operatorname {f}'(-\frac{1}{2})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 594, 920, 613]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 630, 153, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 628, 437, 667]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\int_{-\frac{1}{2}}^{0} \mathrm{f}(x) \mathrm{~d}x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 635, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 82, 698, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 295, 920, 333]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = x^{4} + 2x^{3} + 2x^{2} - 4x - 16\), which crosses the \(x\)-axis at the points \((\alpha , 0)\) and \((\beta , 0)\) where \(\alpha < \beta\). It is given that \(\alpha\) is an integer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 344, 154, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 344, 319, 361]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 344, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 374, 154, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 374, 547, 393]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\beta\) satisfies the equation \(x = \sqrt[3]{}(8 - 2x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 375, 920, 393]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 405, 151, 423]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 405, 920, 439]]<|/det|>
Use an iteration process based on the equation in part (ii) to find the value of \(\beta\) correct to 2 decimal places. Show the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 421, 920, 440]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 466, 94, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 475, 784, 660]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 683, 920, 719]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \sin^{3}2x\cos^{3}2x\). The shaded region shown is bounded by the curve and the \(x\)-axis and its exact area is denoted by \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 732, 153, 750]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 732, 744, 750]]<|/det|>
Use the substitution \(u = \sin 2x\) in a suitable integral to find the value of \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 732, 920, 750]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 765, 153, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 764, 739, 802]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\int_{0}^{k\pi} |\sin^3 2x\cos^3 2x| \mathrm{d}x = 40A\), find the value of the constant \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 771, 920, 789]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 850, 720, 870]]<|/det|>
[Questions 8, 9 and 10 are printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 322, 92]]<|/det|>
Two lines have equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 98, 702, 145]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{r} = \left( \begin{array}{c}5\\ 1\\ -4 \end{array} \right) + s\left( \begin{array}{c}1\\ -1\\ 3 \end{array} \right)\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \mathbf{r} = \left( \begin{array}{c}p\\ 4\\ -2 \end{array} \right) + t\left( \begin{array}{c}2\\ 5\\ -4 \end{array} \right),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 152, 562, 171]]<|/det|>
where \(p\) is a constant. It is given that the lines intersect.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 183, 156, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 183, 776, 202]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(p\) and determine the coordinates of the point of intersection.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 184, 920, 202]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 214, 158, 232]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 214, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the plane containing the two lines, giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\), where \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) and \(d\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 230, 920, 248]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 285, 94, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 275, 154, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 275, 504, 312]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{9 - 7x + 8x^2}{(3 - x)(1 + x^2)}\) in partial fractions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 285, 920, 304]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 336, 153, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 327, 920, 381]]<|/det|>
Hence obtain the expansion of \(\frac{9 - 7x + 8x^2}{(3 - x)(1 + x^2)}\) in ascending powers of \(x\), up to and including the term in \(x^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 408, 104, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 408, 144, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 406, 650, 427]]<|/det|>
Without using a calculator, solve the equation \(\mathrm{i}w^{2} = (2 - 2\mathrm{i})^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 408, 917, 426]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 439, 144, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 439, 193, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 439, 920, 473]]<|/det|>
Sketch an Argand diagram showing the region \(R\) consisting of points representing the complex numbers \(z\) where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 475, 562, 494]]<|/det|>
\[|z - 4 - 4\mathrm{i}|\leqslant 2.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 507, 191, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 505, 824, 526]]<|/det|>
For the complex numbers represented by points in the region \(R\), it is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[363, 532, 633, 552]]<|/det|>
\[p\leqslant |z|\leqslant q\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \alpha \leqslant \arg z\leqslant \beta .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 558, 870, 577]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(p\), \(q\), \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\), giving your answers correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 558, 920, 575]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
